COMP221 - Algorithm Design & Analysis (Spring 2024)

COMP221 - Algorithm Design & Analysis (Spring 2024)

Welcome to the COMP221 (Algorithm Design & Analysis) Course Page. For course policies, please check the syllabus.

Resources

Office Hours

Me and the preceptors will hold OH from the 2nd week of the semester onward. Times can be found in this google calendar. If posted times donât work for you, please email me and we can schedule a separate meeting!

MSCS Slack Channel

In addition to office hours, this course has a dedicated slack channel in the MSCS Slack: #comp221-sp24. Note that while me and the preceptors will be in the chat, occasionally posting announcements, this channel is to faciliate communication amongst students (ask questions to eachother, form study groups, etc.). If you need to contact course staff, please send me or the preceptors an email!

Homework 2

DUE: 3/8/2024

Instructions LaTeX Source

ERRATA:

  • Problem 4b: a valid orderings -> a valid ordering. Please provide an algorithm that finds any valid ordering of letters given the data.
  • Problem 3e: When I say faster here, itâs a rare case of me referring to speed in a non-asymptotic way! Think in terms of number of vertices visited/edges traversed, etc.

Homework 3

DUE: 4/8/2024

Instructions LaTeX Source Sample Code

Errata::

  • For implementation questions, return âinfâ as the cost if the requested structure (SP/MST) doesnât exist.
  • The small puzzle was added 3/29 (previously the assignment only totalled 99 points!).
  • Note that github classroom decided not to use the template as starter code, so iâve linked the sample file-processing and input-handling code above. Regardless, as long as you implement the correct command-line behavior, you should be fine!
  • Problem 1a: The problem says that if a shortest path exists, that path is simple. This neglects to cover cases where multiple shortest paths exist! This should be: if a shortest path exists, there exists a simple shortest path.
  • Problem 1d/e: Assume the $t$ iterated over in the first for loop is different than the $t$ that is the target vertex (mentally replace it with a $tâ$!)
  • Problem 2c: You only need to describe the modification you would make â No need to write pseudocode! Just convey the idea of the modification.
  • Problem 2: It should be that in the example we start with $1c_1$ and end with $1.05c_1$. The problem mistakenly labels the result as $1.05c_2$. Apologies for the typo!
